description: Borrowed from Latin lūcubrātus, perfect passive participle of lūcubrō (“work by candlelight”), from lūx (“light”).

verbs.description: lucubrate (third-person singular simple present lucubrates, present participle lucubrating, simple past and past participle lucubrated)

entries.meaning: (rare) To work diligently by artificial light; to study at night.
To work or write like a scholar.
examples: […]  I shall not hesitate to repeat some of my former thoughts, when lucubrating upon the same subject.
